title: 115_hr5124
content: The Act titled "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes the Community Action Opioid Response Grant Program. The "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" establishes a grant program through the Secretary of Health and Human Services to help Community Action Agencies address the opioid addiction epidemic among low-income individuals and communities. Eligible agencies can apply for grants to expand efforts in identifying and responding to opioid misuse and addiction. Grant funds can be used for various activities to support these goals. The grant program established by the "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" allows eligible agencies to use funds for activities such as public education, outreach, direct services, stabilizing needs, addressing impact on children, and supporting children in foster care affected by opioid addiction. The grant program established by the "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" allows eligible agencies to develop partnerships with various entities to coordinate resources for individuals affected by opioid addiction. It also provides training for agency personnel in identifying at-risk individuals and administering overdose prevention medications. Grant funding is limited to a maximum of $1,000,000 per year for up to three years. The grant program established by the "Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018" provides funding of up to $1,000,000 per year for eligible agencies for a maximum of three years. Recipients must submit annual reports detailing goals, interventions, outcomes, and expenditures, which are made public on the agency's website and the Department of Health and Human Services' website. The Secretary may approve grants exceeding three years based on outcome data or extenuating circumstances. An expedited grant application, review, and award process is also established. The Secretary will publish application process and criteria for grants under the Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018 within 60 days. Criteria include objectives, innovative approaches, evidence of success, and a plan for measuring progress. The grant application process for the Community Action Opioid Response Act of 2018 requires applicants to identify community partners, assess needs related to opioid misuse, ensure funds are not used to replace existing programs, and use evidence-based approaches. The Secretary will establish a Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel of at least 15 individuals with expertise in the opioid epidemic, drug treatment, poverty prevention, child protection, or post-recovery employment. This panel will review and evaluate grant applications, recommending which should receive funding. The Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel will prioritize applications that demonstrate coordination with relevant agencies, leverage non-Federal funds, and propose effective monitoring methodologies to achieve program goals. The grant application review panel will prioritize programs that effectively address opioid addiction, build community capacity, minimize trauma for children in foster care, demonstrate knowledge of local needs, and use innovative approaches. Funding may come from the Office of the Secretary of Health. The Secretary may use appropriated funds for expenses related to the Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel. Grants must be awarded within 120 days of funds availability. $50,000,000 is authorized annually for grants from 2018 to 2022, with a 7% set-aside for grants to Indian tribes or tribal organizations. For grants related to the Community Action Opioid Response Grant Application Review Panel, the Secretary may allocate funds with a 7% set-aside for Indian tribes or tribal organizations. Definitions include the Secretary as the Secretary of Health and Human Services and Community Action Agency as an eligible entity under the Community Services Block Grant Act.
